text: A rocket launch is one of the world’s
most inspiring feats of science.
But what exactly makes these pillars
of propulsion work? To find out,
we’re going to enlist the help
of little green men.
Video games can be complicated,
but they’re not rocket science.
Except when they are.
Like the popular game Kerbal space
program or KSP. In KSP, we’re tasked
with helping the Kerbals – our little
small green guys, get from their home
world into the depths of outer space.
Now how do the Kerbals do it?
The same way we do, with the help of rockets.
One of our Kerbals is sitting in
a rocketship about to lift off.
His ship has solid rocket boosters,
and liquid made engines, which
help them get up and away.
But just how do the solid boosters and liquid
fuel help the Kerbals and us get into space?
Here’s where the rocket science comes in.
In order to get lift off, we need our
rockets to be thrust off the ground.
We do this using a propellant,
a combination of fuel and oxidizer.
The resulting chemical reaction produces
large volumes of very hot gas,
which moves at super high speeds
and propel our rockets up.
Rocket-propelled can be solid
or liquid but they all consist
other fuel and an oxidizer.
Solid rockets are more chemically
stable, but still pack a punch.
You may be familiar with a much smaller
kind of solid rocket already: A firework.

Fireworks use gunpowder or
black powder as a propellant.
Now black powder is the oldest rocket fuel
out there, dating back to 9th century China.
Now our modern space rockets commonly
used a solid propellant called composite
propellant, which contains aluminum
powder as the fuel, and ammonium
perchlorate at the oxidizer,
along with binders and other additives.
Needless to say our modern solid rocket
propellants is much more powerful than gunpowder.
Now when it comes to liquid propellants,
we’ve got a lot of options.
On our space shuttle, in addition to
those solid boosters, there's a tank
of liquid hydrogen that serves as fuel
and liquid oxygen that serves as oxidizer.
Another common much liquid fuel is kerosene.

That's right, the same fuel
you might use in a lamp.
Kerosene used for space travel is called
RP-1 with liquid oxygen again serving as
an oxidizer. RP-1 is heavier than liquid
hydrogen fuel so it's typically used
to fuel rocket at lower stages.
Like when it was used inside Saturn 5's
first stage and with Space X Falcon 9.
Solid or liquid all these propellants
have the same awesome purpose
to generate a write-able explosion.
Now rocket is designed to ensure that
explosion or burn is very controlled
and generate massive amounts of thrust
to get rockets up rather than the unsafe out.
Now helping our Kerbals get into space is fun,
just like our rocket launches back home.
But are rocket launches back home are
massively complicated operations involving
months if not years of research and preparations.
Our real life launches are more complicated
than the Kerbal’s space program.
But the game is a great way to give us
all an introduction to rocket science and it
gives us a chance to play NASA flight director.

Now only we could get our
hands on NASA jump suit.
Thanks for watching and be sure to
check out some of our other videos.
